short.am,ar,bg,bn,ca,cs,da,de,el,en,en_AU,en_G: Automatically blurs sensitive elements on FamilyTreeDNA for screenshots and screencasts.

long.am,ar,bg,bn,ca,cs,da,de,el,en,en_AU,en_G:
Genea FamilyTreeDNA Auto-Blur automatically blurs sensitive items on FamilyTreeDNA pages, making it easy to create secure screenshots and screencasts. The live blurring effect takes place directly in your browser, eliminating the need for manual blurring in editing software. This tool ensures that the original text is never visible during loading and works seamlessly while refreshing or navigating different pages.

Created by Dan Maloney at Genea.ca

Check out Genea Research Tools in the Chrome Web Store, which adds custom features for Ancestry and MyHeritage to enhance your research workflow!

If you encounter any bugs or have suggestions for Genea FamilyTreeDNA Auto-Blur, feel free to contact me at hello@genea.ca.

*How to Use Genea FamilyTreeDNA Auto-Blur*

Install the Extension:
Download and install the extension from the Chrome Web Store.

Access the Extension:
Click the puzzle piece icon in the Chrome menu bar to find Genea FamilyTreeDNA Auto-Blur. For frequent use, pin the icon to the Chrome menu bar by clicking the pushpin icon next to the extension name.

Activate Blurring:
By default, blurring is off. Click the Genea FamilyTreeDNA Auto-Blur icon to activate the blurring effect. When active, a red border will appear around the extension icon, and the "ab" text in the icon will look blurred. Sensitive items on FamilyTreeDNA pages will now be blurred.

Disable Blurring:
Click the extension icon again to disable the blurring effect. The red border will disappear, and the "ab" icon text will become clear. Reload the page to remove the blurring effect.

Blur DNA match profile photos:
If you would like to blur the photo's of your DNA matches as well, right click on the extension in the Chrome menu bar and select "Options". In the options menu click on the checkbox next to "Blur Profile Images" and then click on "Save". The profile photos of your DNA matches will now be blurred.
